et: Middle English {it}after, efter,{/it} going back to Old English {it}æfter,{/it} going back to Germanic {it}*after-{/it} (whence Old Saxon & Old High German {it}aftar{/it} "after, behind," Old Norse {it}eptir,{/it} Gothic {it}aptaro{/it}), perhaps from Indo-European {it}*h{inf}1{/inf}epi-, *h{inf}1{/inf}opi-{/it} "on, at" + {it}*-ter-,{/it} suffix of separation and distinctness {ma}{mat|epi-|}{/ma}

The initial element has alternatively been assigned to Indo-European {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}epo-,{/it} "(away) from" (see {et_link|of:1|of:1}); cf. Sanskrit {it}apataram,{/it} "farther off." In a Germanic context the forms may well have interacted with each other.
shortdef: following in time or place : afterward, behind, later

dt: used to indicate the object of a stated or implied action

dt.t: He's a man {wi}after{/wi} my own heart.

dt: {bc}with the name of or a name derived from that of
{bc}in the characteristic manner of {bc}in imitation of

et: Middle English {it}after, efter,{/it} going back to Old English {it}æfter,{/it} identical with the adverb {it}æfter{/it} {et_link|after:1|after:1} when governing an object
shortdef: subsequent to in time or order
subsequent to and in view of

dt.t: We will come {wi}after{/wi} we make plans.

et: Middle English, elliptically for {it}after that,{/it} from {it}after{/it} {et_link|after:2|after:2} + {it}that{/it} {et_link|that:2|that:2}

dt: {bc}located toward the rear and especially toward the stern of a ship or tail of an aircraft

shortdef: located toward the rear and especially toward the stern of a ship or tail of an aircraft

dt: used with a present participle to indicate action completed and especially just completed

dt.t: the poor old man is {wi}after{/wi} dying on me

et: {et_link|after:2|after:2}, copying Irish prepositional constructions {it}tar éis, i ndiaidh,{/it} etc.
shortdef: —used with a present participle to indicate action completed and especially just completed

dt: used as the first part of a compound to indicate an event or entity that follows or results from the thing denoted by the second part of the compound

used as the first part of a compound to indicate an event or entity of the same nature as the thing denoted by the second part of the compound but which follows that event or entity and is less intense or significant

et: Middle English {it}after,{/it} going back to Old English {it}æfter,{/it} form in composition of adverbial {it}æfter{/it} {et_link|after:1|after:1}
shortdef: —used as the first part of a compound to indicate an event or entity that follows or results from the thing denoted by the second part of the compound

—used as the first part of a compound to indicate an event or entity of the same nature as the thing denoted by the second part of the compound but which follows that event or entity and is less intense or significant

dt: {bc}in spite of considerations or expectations to the contrary {bc}{sx|nevertheless||}

dt.t: decided to take the train {it}after all{/it}
literature which is {it}after all{/it} only a special department of reading

shortdef: in spite of considerations or expectations to the contrary : nevertheless

dt: {bc}engaged in or operating after a legal or conventional closing time

shortdef: engaged in or operating after a legal or conventional closing time

dt: {bc}a party for invited guests that follows a main party or event

shortdef: a party for invited guests that follows a main party or event
